name: N-(4-decylphenyl)-4-methylbenzamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2315
Reason: 4-decylphenyl and methylbenzamide functionalities significantly impact the melting point. The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The decylphenyl group introduces a rigid structure with increased molecular weight, estimated at around +20°C. The methylbenzamide moiety introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10°C. The decyl group introduces additional rigidity and molecular weight, estimated at around +10°C. The phenyl group introduces additional pi-pi interactions and rigidity, estimated at around +20°C. The methyl group introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +5°C. The effects are additive.
